author: fhilip.k
title: CA-tool Dev & Maintenance - AIM
description: The CA-tool needs fund-on-fund updates and maintenance and additional features developed..

f6_assessments.q0: Closely aligned with the challenge setting, since this is a community-led tool which is being maintained and developed in response to community feedback. The tool's popularity & widespread use indicates that CAs must be finding it useful to "improve their work"; and the fact that the proposal team are active CAs themselves means that the proposal is an instance of co-design, and of CAs forming teams to address CA needs.
f6_assessments.q1: Clearly feasible. The tool is already in use and updates have been managed over several funds already, so the team evidently have the skills and experience to deliver this proposal. The timeline is organised and feasible, and includes awareness of the possible risks involved in updating to Vue.js version 3. The budget's new approach, with clear awareness of and inclusion of the costs of management and admin, demonstrates the team's understanding and experience of what will actually be involved in delivering the proposal; and the move to a "treasury" approach with a budget element included for the ongoing development of AIM's longterm sustainability is a very positive change. The only element I feel is slightly missing is an outline of how user feedback on the tool (how easy it is to use, what needs changing, etc) is collected. The wording of the propoosal suggests it's mainly collected via GitHub; but since many CAs are likely to not be GitHub users, it seems probable that at least some of the feedback is collected anecdotally, by the team noting comments and discussion on Catalyst social media (e.g. Discord and Telegram). If this is the case, then the time it takes to do this (and to therefore make the tool responsive to the needs of the whole the CA community, not just those technically-skilled enough to have a GitHub account) should be costed; and if it's not what happens, then it should, in order to ensure a wide range of user opinion is included in planning updates.
f6_assessments.q2: The approach to auditing is transparent and clear, and the project's achievements are easily auditable through a combination of well-defined timings and milestones, simple audit metrics, and anonymous tracking of users. This should be more than sufficient to audit whether the proposal has delivered on its intention. It's also a positive that audit has not been made unsustainably complex, but is in line with the small scale of the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: This is one of those continuing expenses under the hood that everyone takes for granted until its gone.  The CA-Tool is an improvement to the CA process that allows CAs to work outside the outdated and restrictive confines of Ideascale platform.  It allows us (I am using it right now!) to distribute our assessments more evenly and to where they are needed most, by showing us how many assessments proposals have.  It also gathers in one place a lot of the resources CAs need to do their job properly, such as links to the guidelines and handy lists of considerations for CAs to check off as they assess a proposal.  Additionally it allows CAs to work more efficiently by making browsing proposals faster and easier, helping us keep track of what we have done and submitted, and giving us larger fields into which to compose our assessments, instead of the cramped windows on ideascale.  For most CAs the tool is indisposable.  But it needs updated every fund, and it needs tested and maintained.  Additionally, as Catalyst evolves, the tools need to evolve too, so a skeleton crew maintaining it as a hobby isn't going to cut it.  With this funding proposal carrying it all the way through Fund 10, you won't find a better deal.
f6_assessments.q1: The team has proven reliable and committed and it has grown to add even more developers who can assist.  They have effectively communicated the build requirements and what the nature of the updates required and schedule will be, as well as provided a budget list for each of the rollouts.  They have also included an experimental "Guild Fee" which will go towards trying to implement a treasury that can add sustainable bridging between funds, and possibly even develop into something more sustainable.  There really aren't any risks tied to this project:  they are doing what they have done from the start, and none of their planned updates look like risks to crash the platform. Their insistence on community feedback and testing protocols indicates that CAs will have a tool that works for them and be able to trust that the improvements are successful.
f6_assessments.q2: This is an Opensource code (though, sadly, not yet forked...we need a dark-mode designer to grab this and get instant market share, lol) so there will be no trouble keeping up with commits and issues in their Github.  Additionally, you see the AIM toolmakers everyday in the Catalyst ecosystem, so keeping in touch with the developers is a non-issue, whether on their own dedicated channels, or any of the many community channels they frequent.  The funding isn't an auditing issue for them, as it will be paid out quickly, but they already have a protocol in place for dealing with the 6 month reporting cycle and delivery of the final report.  In the meantime they will have all of the improvements and updates in the timeline to report on, so I have no doubt they will be able to bring the funding to an agreeable closure.

f6_assessments.q0:
As a (v)CA i've used the CA-tool over the past two funds for both the assessment and review stages and it has significantly increased my productivity, and i believe this to be he case for the majority of (v)CAs who have chose to use this tool. It gives us the ability to filter proposal  and assessments by tags, challenge, length and provides and update on the number of assessments/reviews per proposal/assessment which helps the CA community focus the work where it is needed. Providing a more permanent funding will provide an extra incentive for the AIM team to further develop an improve this tool.

IOG still maintains a significant oversight over the whole Project Catalyst project, and as a community we often find difficult to push through with improvements and/or innovations. This tool is fully designed by the community and for the community and it is my hope that it will gain more and more prominence in Project Catalyst and for this reason i give this proposal the maximum rating for Impact.

The proposal aligns perfectly with the challenge brief specifically to the "Number of maintenance proposals and groups created" KPI, but also on the "Number of new tools developed" KPI as the proposers plan to introduce new features
f6_assessments.q1:
This tool has already been in operation for quite a few funds now and it's been successful in term of community reception so it's clear that this is a feasible proposal. It's also clear that the team that created such a tool have the experience to maintain it but also the technical skills to introduce further improvements. Victor, Lucio and Phill are very active members of the community, not just in terms of the maintenance of the tool, but on every aspect of Project Catalyst. They are engaged in most discussions, have worked as CA's and vCA carrying out assessments and reviews, participated in a number of different proposal in different challenges, being elected for Catalyst circle, etc. This to say that they are fully aware of the community "wants and needs"

The proposal presents a plan with what tasks will be carried out at each stage, including the description of the technical improvements (e.g. updating to Vue.js 3). The proposal mentions that new features will be developed in both funds. A bit more detail on what these features will do or cover would have strengthen this proposal and allowed the community to assess the success/usefulness of these.

The main risk for this project is that Victor, Lucio and/or Phill become to busy by other projects that they don't dedicate enough time to maintain and improve the CA-tool. This risk has been correctly addressed in the proposal and it's great that two new developers were onborded to help with the workload.

The budget is laid down in identifiable items and reasonable amount, perhaps even a bit too low
f6_assessments.q2:
As the CA-tool is open source and available for anyone to see on Github, the community will easily be able to follow progress of this proposal. These are correctly described in the audibility section.

In terms of measure of success this are also correctly identified, with the most important on being the ability to measure the adoption of the tool. I would have liked to see a bit more detailed metrics here such as % Increase in number of CA's using the tool or % Increase in number of assessments/reviews carried out with the tool.

The problem this proposal is targeting is succinctly described i.e. the need to maintain and update the tool and the solution in terms of "what" and "how" will be done is also clearly described throughout the proposal

f6_assessments.q0: Yes it does. Updating the existing CA tools will be helpful for all the community memebers to use tool much more effectively and that will help them to easily review and asses proposal using various filters, tags and much more functions.
f6_assessments.q1: yes the team is having good experienced people including creators of the CA-tool, active community members and building as a part of AIM. That will be ideal team for this proposal to be implemented successfully with clear plan and strategy.
f6_assessments.q2: Yes they provided detailed the information about the things which we can add to existing CA tools in order to make it more functional and easy to use for people they also mentioned technical details and library details and their plan to successfully audit the progress and execute.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal’s aim is to keep the maintenance and add new features of the already existing CA Tool, that the proposers have developed a few funds ago.
The tool has proven already to be of good use to community advisors, I have personally used it countless times and it has been helpful in finding proposals to assess, especially in the last days of the review stage, when some of them have only few assessments. On top of that, it is open source, allowing thus anyone knowledgeable to build on top of it, add functionalities or revisions for themselves. 
I find the proposal to be an ideal fit to the current challenge, as it would positively impact the CAs work and thus the entire Catalyst ecosystem.
f6_assessments.q1:
The plan and timeline are detailed, split into objectives for Fund9 and Fund10, thus offering a clear picture of the work that will be put, in order to complete the project.
The budget is quite extensively broken down, with short explanations and looks reasonable and realistic.
The proposers have provided sufficient details about their role in the Catalyst community, skills and previous work and have attached links for verification.
I find there’s no need for any additional information, that would aid in the assessment of this stage of the proposal.
f6_assessments.q2:
The description for the development progress is well illustrated, and offers the opportunity for the community to verify it, through Github commits, issues opened, resolved and so on.
The success description is realistic, achievable and easy to verify, since the community tool is open to anyone and they will also start using an anonymous user tracker, in order to have better adoption metrics.

f6_assessments.q0: The existing tool is community-driven and supported and delivers tremendous value for the CA community. All software needs to be maintained and updated, and this proposal effectively addresses the challenge by anticipating the changing needs of the CA role and outlines a good plan to ensure there are development resources allocated to maintain and upkeep the tool and to add new features and functionality when needed.
f6_assessments.q1: The team has already delivered a great tool, which is proof that the team is able to continue to improve and maintain the tool for CAs.
f6_assessments.q2: The team has outlined a reasonable budget and a timeline of what and when they will deliver. The KPIs are clearly outlined and the various roles for the project have been well thought out and I like that they include management, and especially testing budget. As a software development manager in a previous life, I know that it's easy to overlook the testing and QA of a software projects, so it's nice to see it clearly outlined in their plan. I also appreciate that they are asking for funding over two funds, which will allow them to keep heads down delivering value instead of chasing another round of proposals in F10.

f6_assessments.q0:

As pointed out in the proposal, is is indeed aligned with challenge, addressing the kpi 'Number of maintenance proposals and groups created'.

 I liked the new features of providing a match between basic skills from proposal and assessor.

It would also be nice to bring here how many asessors (or how many single visits the website has) to see how the community uses the tool and  make the importance of the tool clearer, specially for those who dont know about it. it could also be brought its increase over time, since it was created.
f6_assessments.q1:
As the proposal is to keep the existing tool operating, I dont see major risks in the feasibility. 
The timeline is very clar, broken down by fund weeks and includes main deliverables. 
costs breakdown are fair and listed by type of acitivities. It could also include the number of hours of each.
Finally, team is experieced, with background in Cardano, UI/UX and software development, which are the main required capabilities for keeping this tool running and widely used.
f6_assessments.q2:
kpis suggested are good but could have some targets, even if it was a percentual increase in relation to last fund.
Number of users could also be a kpi with target (at least an increase from F9 to F10). This would help to assess the tool communitaction quality.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal is focused in the CA tool and, therefore, brings improvements to the CA process. It is bringing new features and updates to the CA tool. However, it could be improved by considering a wider range of improvements in the CA tool (allowing users to avoid two platforms, Ideascale and CA tool; bringing automated information during the assessment phase; or any of the other much-needed improvements, and that the community has been suggesting).
f6_assessments.q1: The team has given information to its qualification and the proposal will be likely well implemented. The budget is reasonable and the milestones and deliverables are achievable. Therefore, this proposal deserves a score of 5.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal is clear on its solutions and deliverables, and the roadmap applies to the next two funds, which is also reasonable. The success of this proposal can be verified by the community in the CA tool. Although the proposers could have considered more risks and limitations of the proposal, it is structured enough to be executed and verified.

f6_assessments.q0: Anyone involved in Catalyst's proposal QA stage does not even need to go back to the early stages funding to be introduced to and be aware of the CA-tool. In fact, this very funding round counts this tool in its inventory and is currently being relied on all over the globe as I type these words. The very reason for its existence is currently happening and for this, it's undeniable that it completely addresses the challenge and I am in full agreement. For someone who does not get to attend the townhall regularly and when its live, I have at least seen Lucio once on-screen demo-ing the tool, answering every question and being open to a multitude of questions from the audience. To me, this tool represents so much of the can-do, iterative approach of Catalyst where everyone who can contribute do. It is almost a pity that such a valuable tool requires constant funding submissions to maintain its development and upkeep given its operational criticality in Catalyst activities. I for one would cast a yes vote to ensuring it simply gets funded by IOG until we move to the Voltaire era. Thank you Lucio.
f6_assessments.q1: There had been so many previous funding rounds which can attest to the functionality and usefulness of the CA-tool. I don't need to rely on my background as an assessor of tenders for a university to place my full confidence and agreement on the experience of the proposer and the plan presented in this proposal. That the development described aims to enhance the tool for Funds 9 & 10 is clear. But what provides greater confidence is the specific listing of the improvements for funds 9 & 10 separately, which the proposer didn't need to do but for the sake of abiding by the CA assessment standards and guidelines, has been presented as such. This demonstrates a level of professionalism which does not take short-cuts and is reflected in the team's approach and output.  The amount requested is very reasonable and this is supported by clear descriptions of how the budget is being allocated. The timelines as described also look like the improvements to the tool will arrive just in time for the next funding round. Overall, a very clear and commendable proposal.
f6_assessments.q2: The Github repository of the CA-tool's code has been made available and is open source meaning anyone who wants to take a look and audit the progress can. Anyone who can themselves improve upon the code is even invited. Even non-programmers who may not to understand the code can base their analysis of any work being conducted by the KPIs listed. And I am sure that Townhalls prior to funding rounds 9 and 10 will include on-going progress reports and demos for the new functionalities. Overall, I highly agree to the auditability of this proposal in terms of its progress & I am confident, based on experience and awareness of the team, that it will meet its goals.

f6_assessments.q2: The information provided in this proposal is certainly sufficient to audit the progress. Key metrics, goals and success criteria are easily reach and evaluated by community. We (CAs) can not wait to use the newly improved CA tool.

f6_assessments.q2:

From fund9 we’ll anonymously track users that will use the tool, in order to have some hard metrics to measure the current adoption of the tool.

f6_assessments.q0:
Message to voters: CA-Tool is critical for Catalyst project Success, and this proposal explains very well why we should invest in this tool.
How uneasy and inefficient the CA Job would become without this tool is clearly stated by the proposal: back to spreadsheets, drop in productivity and quality for reviews, lower quality information for voters.  
While AIM dev team as in the past requested funding retroactively, this proposal intends to on board devs in advance to allow tool maintenance, adaptation to future change in Catalyst process, development of new features.
I strongly agree that this proposal effectively addresses the challenge, and this 5-star score should be 6 !
f6_assessments.q1:
CA-Tool is up and running, and its development team known as AIM is skilled and has experience in the Catalyst Project. Many details are given about the AIM team members, showing that they gather the skills necessary to keep this project successful.
That’s probably why the feasibility part of the proposal is also very well written: milestones, budget breakdown is detailed and relevant.
f6_assessments.q2:
CA-Tool is an open source project and has a Github depository. Following the activity on Github (commits, issues opened / resolved etc) offers to the community the ability to monitor the development of the project.
Besides, the detailed milestone enables to follow that they follow the targeted roadmap.

solution: Provide funding to maintain the CA-tool for two funds.
experience: Creators of the CA-tool, active community members and building as a part of AIM.
